summary: William G. Miller appears in several documents related to the Senate Select Committee (SSC) investigations into intelligence activities in the 1970s. The documents suggest that Miller was a staff member of the Senate Select Committee, as indicated by a memorandum updating security clearances. He is mentioned in transcripts of Senate Select Committee hearings, indicating his involvement in the committee's work. The documents do not explicitly state his specific role or responsibilities within the committee, but his presence in the transcripts and security clearance listings implies he was an active participant in the committee's investigations.
significance: Based on the provided documents, William G. Miller's significance lies in his involvement with the Senate Select Committee investigating intelligence activities. While the documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, the committee's broader investigation into intelligence agencies and their activities could potentially uncover information relevant to the assassination. His role as a staff member suggests he had access to sensitive information and participated in the committee's inquiries.
